title: Millionaire’s son who caused death of toddler walks free after just seven months
text:
Antonio Boparan, 32, was as previously convicted of dangerous driving in April 2008 (Picture : SWNS)

A multimillionaire’s son who caused the death of a toddler in a horror crash, has been released from prison after just seven months.

Cerys Edwards died nine years after Antonio Boparan, 32, ploughed his Range Rover Sport into a jeep while speeding at 70mph in a 30mph zone.

The tot was left with devastating injuries including a broken spine, which left her brain damaged and paralysed in the crash in November 2016.

Days after celebrating her first birthday, Cerys needed round-the-clock care and was permanently dependant on a ventilator.

She had to undergo dozens of major operations over the years, but died at Birmingham Children’s hospital on October 17, 2015 – just a month before her tenth birthday.

Boparan, heir to a £800 million chicken fortune, was previously convicted of dangerous driving in April 2008 but released just six months into a 21 month sentence.

Following Cery’s death, police reopened the case and a post mortem revealed the youngster had died as a result of injuries sustained in the collision.

Cerys Edwards was left paralysed after the crash (Picture: SWNS)

Boparan, of Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, was charged with causing death by dangerous driving, 13 years after the collision.

He was jailed for 18 months in March after he admitted the charge at Birmingham Crown Court.

But today it emerged Boparan has been released from prison after just seven months behind bars.

The Edwards family were on their way home after delivering Christmas presents, when Boparan crashed into them on the wrong side of the road on November 11, 2006.

He faced up to 14 years in prison if Cerys had died at the time, but instead served just six months.

The outrage over the sentence sparked a national outcry and a campaign was launched demanding Government action.

Labour’s former Justice Minister Jack Straw called the Edwards family himself to give them the news about what became known as ‘Cerys’s Law’.

Antonio Boparan Singh has been released from prison after just seven months (Picture: SWNS)

As a result of the changes, anyone convicted of causing serious injury by dangerous driving now faces up to five years in prison instead of the previous maximum of two.

Cerys was awarded £5million compensation in 2012, along with a guaranteed annual payout of £450,000 to help pay for her annual care bill.

At the time Judge Martin McKenna, sitting at Birmingham County Court, described it as the ‘saddest and most tragic case’ he had ever come across.

The Range Rover Boparan was driving in 2006 was owned by his wealthy parents, Ranjit and Baljinder Boparan, who run the 2 Sisters Food Group – the third largest food company in the UK by turnover with an annual revenue of £3.4billion.

Speaking after Cerys’ death, grieving dad Gareth Edwards, 51, paid tribute to his daughter whose smile ‘would melt the hearts of anyone’.

Gareth, a builder from Sutton Coldfield, added: ‘Police have found his actions caused the death of my daughter so he is a child killer, simple as that.

‘He killed my daughter.

‘I want to see him in that dock again, facing charges of manslaughter or murder. He used that motor vehicle to kill my daughter.

‘I cannot turn the clock back – my daughter is gone and is six feet under – all I can do is fight for justice for that little girl.’

Mr Edwards also branded the 18 month sentence handed down to Boparan as an insult.

He said: ‘Boparan will only serve around 15 months behind bars in total for killing a child and destroying several lives, which is a complete insult.

‘We have been left with a life sentence without our beautiful little girl, whose precious life was stolen from us.’
